STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 7, 2020
TaSeanda Johnson
Wayne County DHHS - Western
27540 Michigan Avenue
Inkster, MI 48141
RE: License #: CP820201497
Wayne County DHHS - Western
27540 Michigan Avenue
Inkster, MI 48141
Dear Ms. Johnson/Ms. Ray:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 10/2/20.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, policies and ISEP requirements, a
written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter, must be completed on the new CAP form and include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-4532/enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP820201497
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: TaSeanda Johnson
Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Name of Facility: Wayne County DHHS - Western
Facility Address: 27540 Michigan Avenue
Inkster, MI 48141
Facility Telephone #: (313) 934-8910
Original Issuance Date: 05/01/1992
Service Types: PLACE FOSTER CHILDREN
INDEPENDENT LIVING
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The exit conference for this review was held on 10/02/20 via Microsoft Teams.
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police or the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law enforcement agency where the person
usually resides.
(ii) An entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state or Canadian provincial law
enforcement agency where the person usually resides.
One of two interns did not have an ichat prior to her start
date. The intern started working on 9/2/20. Her ichat was
not run until 9/29/20 after this audit commenced.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
One of two interns did not have a central registry clearance
prior to her start date. The intern started working on 9/2/20.
Her clearance was not run until 9/29/20 after this audit
commenced.
4

R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All of the
following apply:
(i) A statement from a parent or licensed medical authority
which indicates that immunizations are current or
contraindicated is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
(ii) A copy of a waiver addressed to the department of
community health signed by the parent stating immunizations
are not being administered due to religious, medical, or other
reasons is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the
waiver is unavailable, then immunizations shall begin within 30
calendar days of placement.
Child 1 entered care on 1/3/20. As of 2/3/20, the child’s
immunization record was not in MICSACWIS. The rule
indicates if documentation of immunization is unavailable, then
immunizations shall begin within 30 days of placement.
The agency did not check that the child’s shots were up to date
during her first 30 days of care. On 10/1/20, this audit revealed
still no evidence the child was current on vaccinations. On
10/5/20, the agency determined from the doctor the child’s shots
were indeed current, however the doctor’s office had misspelled
the child’s name therefore verification was not in MISACWIS.
Child 2 entered care on 2/7/20. At that time, her immunization
record showed she had been overdue for a Hepatitis A shot
since 7/23/18. The child was seen for a well-child exam on
2/12/20. On that date, she was not given the shot. As of
10/5/20, the child’s Hepatitis A still has not been given.
Two of eight foster children were not current on
immunizations or did not have verification that
immunizations were current within 30 days of entering care.
(Repeat violations from 2019 & 2018)
5

R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(2) An agency shall have documentation from the medical or
dental provider of all medical and dental care received by a
foster child.
Based on uploaded screenshots, it appears Child 1 was seen
timely for 9, 12 and 15-month well child exams. However, the
completed exam forms not available and therefore there was no
documentation the forms were signed by the medical provider.
Based on uploaded screenshots, it appears Child 3 was seen
timely for an initial well child exam. However, the completed
exam form was unavailable and therefore there was no
documentation the form was signed by the medical provider.
Two of eight foster child were missing documentation of
four well-child exams signed by the medical provider.
(Repeat violation from 2019)
R 400.12418 Development of service plans / (DHHS Policy 722-08C -
PATPs must be signed by caregiver)
(5) An agency shall involve the foster parents in the
development of service plans to enable the foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the foster parent's role in
assisting the agency in carrying out the plan.
Eight of twenty-three PATPs were not signed timely in the
usual manner or any other alternative manner by the
caregivers for three of eight foster children. Due to COVID
each worker was given the opportunity to produce
verification of alternative methods of obtaining the
signatures during the audit.
(Repeat violation from 2019 & 2018)
6

R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
Monthly budget forms are used to verify that IL youth are
managing their expenditures. One of one IL youth was missing
monthly budget forms for the months of April, May, June, July,
August and September 2020. On 9/29/20, the worker stated
she did not complete these forms with the youth.
DHHS management’s stance was that IL budgets were not
required in April, May and June due to COVID-19. However,
this is not the case. The worker could have reviewed the
youth’s budgets with him, filled out the forms and sought
alternative methods of signature via video conference.
On 10/5/20, DHHS management produced 3 budget forms
signed by the worker and youth dated July, August and
September 2020. It is peculiar that these forms were produced
when the worker had already reported she had not done them.
Neither management nor the worker would explain how the
newly produced documents came to be. These forms were not
accepted as they were not provided on-site at the time of the
audit.
Five of six monthly budgets were not completed with one of
one IL youth.
7

R 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
On 9/29/20, the IL worker stated she was unaware there was a
contract between the agency and the youth. On 10/5/20, DHHS
management produced three contracts signed timely by the
worker and youth. Again it is peculiar the documents were
produced when the worker did not know they were required.
Neither management nor the worker would explain how the
newly produced documents came to be. These contracts were
not accepted as they were not provided on-site at the time of the
audit.
One of one IL youth was missing the initial contract
agreement and two subsequent contract agreements that
were required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which
will be the primary tracking system and satisfy federal
reporting requirements.
The MISACWIS tracking system is not being fully
maintained/updated. Multiple documents (medical exam
forms, signed PATPs, IL budgets and contracts, and other
forms) for several children were not uploaded into
MISACWIS in a timely manner. Many documents that were
completed months earlier were not unloaded until after I
8

was on-site for the audit and had chosen a sample of child
records to review.
*Note - A previous corrective action plan submitted by the
agency indicated that time would be designated each week
for social services workers to upload documents into
MISACWIS. Despite employees working remotely, annual
licensing audits continue and all aspects of the statewide
tracking system must still be maintained.
ISEP 6.43 Mental health screening within 30 days of entry to foster
care.
Four of eight foster children did not have timely ASQs
(Repeat non-compliance from 2019 & 2018)
ISEP 6.49 Quarterly medical passports
Three quarterly medical passports were missing or were
uploaded but not signed by the caregiver for two of eight
children.
(Repeat non-compliance from 2019 & 2018)
3. Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS policy violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional DHHS Policy requirements except for the following:
722.06B,pg 11 FTM – Efforts to involve incarcerated parent(s)
One of eight foster children has two incarcerated parents.
There was no documentation that efforts were made to
involve the incarcerated parents in the development of their
child’s service plans (ie, mailing the PATPs) or family team
meetings (via phone or video conference). The worker said
she was not aware there should be efforts to involve
incarcerated parents.
9

IV. CONSULTATION:
It is recommended that supervisors ensure that documents are not being uploaded
into MISACWIS until the documents are complete. Incomplete and unsigned
documents are misleading, bog down the system and should not be uploaded.
Documents should be uploaded in a timely manner and labelled appropriately.
If a biological parent cannot be located to sign a PATP within 30 days after
the plan is completed, the worker can date the parent signature line (within 30
of the report), write “parent cannot be located” on the parent signature line, sign
and date the worker line and then upload the PATP.
Obtaining caregiver and parent signatures on PATPs beyond 30 days after the
plan is completed is non-compliant and defeats the intent of the rule and policy.
If the initial mental health screening (ASQ) is not completed by the doctor, it
is the social service worker’s responsibility to assure that one is completed and
uploaded within 30 days of the child entering care. It is recommended that
supervisors verify that mental health screenings are completed and uploaded in a
timely manner.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no DCWL complaints received or investigations completed during
this licensing period. There were no safety alerts identified by the DCWL
Analyst.
The following items were cited and acceptable corrective action plans submitted
for the Renewal Inspection of 2019:
R 400.12405 (3) (a – j) Change of placement
R 400.12413 (1) (d) (ii), (1) (f) & (2) Medical and dental care policy
R 400.12418 (2) (a) & (b) Development of service plans
ISEP 6.49 Quarterly medical passports signed
ISEP 6.33c PATPs signed by parent/guardian
DHHS Policy 802 Mental health screening within 30 days of entry
DHHS Policy 722-08C PATPs signed by caregiver
DHHS Policy 722-6H Four visits in the first two months of placement
DHHS Policy 722-06I Monthly sibling visits for siblings who are split
DHHS Policy 722-06B Quarterly FTMs
V. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MSA requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
10

acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
October 7, 2020
________________________________________
Deborah Will Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 7, 2020
_______________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
11
